channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Turkey Awaits Outcome of Pivotal Elections
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is facing the fiercest political challenge of his 20 years in power. With votes still being tallied, the state-run news agency reports that he has just under 50 percent. He needs a majority to avoid a runoff.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: In Blow to Junta, Thai Voters Overwhelmingly Back Opposition Parties
item.description: Thais on Sunday cast votes against their military leaders, backing instead a populist political mainstay and a progressive upstart bent on shaking up the status quo.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, leader of the Move Forward Party and prime ministerial candidate, in Bangkok on Sunday night.

item.title: Kenyan Preacher Told Followers Starvation Was Their Salvation
item.description: Hundreds were drawn to a remote wilderness in southeastern Kenya by the End Times preaching of pastor Paul Mackenzie. Relatives and ex-members tried to intervene, but some did not want to be rescued.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: After bodies were exhumed, holes were left in the ground at a mass gravesite in the Shakahola Forest in Kenya.

item.title: Zelensky Visits Germany, Praising Weapons Pledge and Seeking Jets
item.description: The Ukrainian president was received with military honors in Berlin, where he thanked Germany’s leaders for standing with his country.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany traded compliments in front of reporters on Sunday.

item.title: Brief Rocket Fire Disrupts Gaza Cease-Fire. How Long Can the Truce Last?
item.description: Another violent escalation in Gaza ended in another cease-fire. But it did not completely halt the rocket fire and the region’s instability means the next conflagration is never far away.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Children amid the rubble of a building hit by an Israeli airstrike in the center of the Gaza Strip on Saturday.

item.title: Cyclone Mocha Makes Landfall, Killing at Least 6
item.description: The storm, which made landfall near Myanmar’s border with Bangladesh on Sunday, has so far not led to the humanitarian catastrophe that officials feared.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Judson Jones, Jin Yu Young and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Sai Aung Main/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Residents check out the damage in Kyauktaw, in Myanmar’s Rakhine State, on Sunday.

item.title: As Ukraine Makes Inroads in Bakhmut, Devastation Still Reigns
item.description: The fight for Bakhmut is now the war’s single longest and bloodiest battle. Although the Ukrainians are making small gains, Russia still controls about 90 percent of the largely ruined city.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers west of Bakhmut. Russia and Ukraine have been locked in intense fighting over the city since last fall.

item.title: India Struggles to Eradicate an Old Scourge: Witch Hunting
item.description: Once driven largely by superstition, the brutal practice is now often simply a tool to oppress women, in many cases violently.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Samyukta Lakshmi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Durga Mahato in the temple near where she was dumped, unconscious, after being beaten and accused of being a witch, in the eastern Indian state of Jharkhand.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Thailand Votes for Change
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate Pita Limjaroenrat, center, outside the party’s headquarters in Bangkok on Sunday.

item.title: Who Will Win Turkey’s Election? Astrologers Find Answers in the Stars
item.description: Amid economic uncertainty and the most competitive elections in years, interest in fortune tellers has surged in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: The main opposition candidate, Kemal Kilicdaroglu, wore a martenitsa, or “wish ribbon,” on his wrist as he cast his ballot at a polling station in Ankara on Sunday.

item.title: Rules for Pentagon Use of Proxy Forces Shed Light on a Shadowy War Power
item.description: Newly disclosed documents include Special Operations forces directives for managing counterterrorism and irregular warfare surrogate fighters.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Julia Nikhinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon keeps secret much about its proxy force operations.

item.title: ‘The Diplomat’ vs. Reality
item.description: A popular show on Netflix is about the glamorous job of a U.S. ambassador. But is it realistic?
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:description: Keri Russell as Kate Wyler in “The Diplomat.”

item.title: Thailand’s Election: What to Watch and What’s at Stake
item.description: The vote is seen as a referendum on the military, which has ruled Thailand for nine years. Results could determine the path for democracy in the country.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A voter casting his ballot during early voting at a polling station in Narathiwat, Thailand, on Sunday, a week ahead of the May 14 general election.

item.title: Israel and Islamic Jihad Agree to Cease-Fire After 5 days of Violence
item.description: Mediation efforts led by Egypt were expected to end fighting that has outlasted previous clashes between Israel and the militant group in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Standing amid the rubble of a building hit by an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, in the Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Defeat for Modi’s Party in South India Heartens His Rivals
item.description: An overturn in Karnataka is a morale boost for the beleaguered opposition Congress party. But defeating the B.J.P. nationally remains a long shot.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Supporters of the Indian National Congress celebrating initial results from elections in Karnataka on Saturday.

item.title: Canada’s ‘Most Photographed House’ May Meet the Wrecking Ball
item.description: Municipal orders to tear down or fix the dilapidated 19th-century Ontario farmhouse have devastated photographers who see in it the faded grandeur of a bygone era.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Peter Anderson, whose grandparents bought the homestead by the shore of Lake Erie in 1908, said he felt unfairly targeted by a tear-down order, which came in response to an anonymous citizen complaint.

item.title: Germany Announces Its Biggest Ukraine Aid Package Yet
item.description: The nearly $3 billion package is part of an effort by both sides to reset rocky relations, which have become increasingly important to maintaining European unity in backing the war.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The 28th Mechanized Brigade of the Ukrainian Army in an armored vehicle during an operation near Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: The Mysteries of Zelda
item.description: Countless people find joy, frustration and discovery in video games.
item.dc:creator: Jason M. Bailey
item.category: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom (Video Game)

item.title: Calgary’s New Mayor Says Her City Is More Than an Oil Town
item.description: Jyoti Gondek wants to prepare Alberta’s largest city for a future in which oil and gas are no longer a major part of the world’s energy mix.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jyoti Gondek, who became Calgary’s mayor in 2021, believes her city’s ethnic diversity helps it grow.

item.title: At Eurovision, Ukrainians Find Community Far From Home
item.description: This year, the competition is hosted by Liverpool, England, on behalf of Ukraine. A discounted ticket plan means thousands of displaced Ukrainians can attend.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tanya Kuzmenko, center, watches a performance this week by a former Eurovision winner in the EuroVillage fan area in Liverpool, England. Kuzmenko is one of thousands of displaced Ukrainians who settled in Britain after Russia invaded their home country.

item.title: It’s May in Rome: A Time to Revere, and Fear, Fava Beans
item.description: Although favism, a blood disorder that can cause a violent reaction to fava beans, lurks throughout Italy, many Romans look forward to May, when the legumes are in season.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sara Autieri selling fresh beans at the Festival for the Fava Bean outside Rome on Sunday.

item.title: Erdogan’s Loss in Turkey’s Election Would Stir Anxiety in Moscow
item.description: European leaders would be delighted to have “an easier Turkey,” while Russia could lose an important economic and diplomatic partnership should the Turkish leader lose power in Sunday’s elections.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia share an authoritarian streak and confrontational attitudes toward the West, emphasizing historical grievances against other world powers.

item.title: Pope Assures Zelensky He’s in ‘Constant Prayer’ For Peace in Ukraine
item.description: The Ukrainian president’s talks with the pope and Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni came at a potentially pivotal moment in the war with Russia, as Kyiv’s forces make advances near the key city of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met Pope Francis in the Vatican on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Advances Near Bakhmut Expose Rifts in Russian Forces
item.description: Russia’s pro-war bloggers were quick to claim that Ukraine’s long-anticipated counteroffensive had begun, but Ukrainian officials downplayed the advances.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen near Bakhmut on Friday. Tens of thousands of soldiers are believed to have died in the battle for the city in eastern Ukraine, making it a symbolic objective for Ukraine and Russia.

item.title: Some U.S. Solar Makers Criticize Biden’s Tax Credits as Too Lax on China
item.description: U.S.-based manufacturers of solar products say rules issued by the Biden administration on Friday will “cement China’s dominance” over the solar industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Ivan Penn
item.media:description: Workers install solar panels on a house in Salt Lake City. The Biden administration is trying to spur the construction of more solar factories in the United States.

item.title: Erdogan Amassed Power in Turkey. He Could Still Lose This Election.
item.description: Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has tilted the political playing field in his favor over the past two decades, concentrating power in his own hands. Still, he faces a stiff challenge in Sunday’s election.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers pass an election poster of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan at a market in the city of Kayseri last month.

item.title: The Biggest Explosion in the Cosmos Just Keeps Going
item.description: For three years, telescopes have monitored “one of the most luminous” events ever: a supermassive black hole consuming a gigantic cloud of interstellar gas.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.category: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Journal)

item.title: Ukraine’s Offensive Could Set Stage for Diplomacy With Russia, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: While exploring endgames, Biden aides say they reject any push for peace talks — including from China — that would freeze the current front lines and Russia’s gains.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training near Kyiv. The country’s leaders say they will not agree to talks until they have pushed back Russian forces.

item.title: Iran Releases 2 French Citizens From Detention
item.description: Benjamin Brière and Bernard Phelan had been accused of spying, which they denied. They had protested their captivity with hunger strikes, and their families had fought for their release.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Families and friends of a growing number of Europeans imprisoned in Iran gathered in Paris in January to call for their release.

item.title: What I’m Reading: Summer-Snobs Edition
item.description: Tales of status, those who have it and those who want it, are on my list.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Zack DeZon for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Pineapple Street,” by Jenny Jackson, is set among the ultrarich of Brooklyn Heights in New York City.

item.title: China’s Economic Needs May Take a Back Seat to Security
item.description: Xi Jinping wants to insulate China from perceived threats from the West. He also wants to promote the country as deserving of foreign investment and clout. Can he do both?
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: China’s foreign minister, Qin Gang, at a forum under the theme of “Chinese Modernization and the World,” in Shanghai last month.

item.title: Wendy Sherman, the Deputy Secretary of State, Plans to Retire
item.description: She began her first diplomatic job 30 years ago, led talks on the Iran nuclear deal and grapples with China and Russia. She is also the first woman to be deputy secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Wendy R. Sherman has been a fixture in foreign policy circles in Washington and capitals worldwide as the go-to diplomat for tough negotiations with U.S. rivals and adversaries.

item.title: Thousands of Guns Turned in After 2 Mass Shootings in Serbia
item.description: The unregistered weapons were handed over to the authorities as the government vows to disarm the country after two mass shootings.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Joe Orovic
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral on Saturday in Malo Orasje, a village south of Belgrade, Serbia, for victims of a mass shooting in which eight people were killed.

item.title: From Rap Star to Engineer to Young Mayor Demolishing Swaths of Kathmandu
item.description: A music idol in his early 20s and then an engineer, Balen, 33, next won an upset victory as mayor of Nepal’s capital, inspiring a wave of young politicians. Now, he’s tearing down parts of the city.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Balen, wearing his trademark black-on-black blazer and jeans, paired with small, square black sunglasses, in Kathmandu, in November.

item.title: China Orders Tesla to Recall 1.1 Million Vehicles Over Braking Risks
item.description: Defects on certain Tesla models could lead drivers to step on the accelerator pedals for longer than necessary, increasing the risk of collisions, China’s market regulator says.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Claire Fu
item.media:description: Tesla Model 3 vehicles at a factory in Shanghai in 2020. China’s regulator has recalled several models manufactured between 2019 and April of this year.

item.title: A New Round of Middle East Fighting
item.description: The death of an imprisoned Palestinian militant leader on a hunger strike prompted new skirmishing.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Palestinian Islamic Jihad leader Khader Adnan during a 2015 rally in the West Bank.

item.title: Fighting Between Israel and Islamic Jihad: Where Things Stand
item.description: Exchanges of fire continued on Friday despite overnight mediation efforts for a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Walking through the rubble of a house that was hit by an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, on Friday.

item.title: It’s Called Eurovision. So Why Is Australia Part of It?
item.description: Australia has been one of the event’s biggest markets outside Europe. Since 2015, it has been a contestant, but that may end after this year’s final.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The Australian band Voyager performing at Eurovision, in Liverpool, England, on Thursday.

item.title: China Will Send an Envoy to Russia and Ukraine to Help Negotiate an End to the War
item.description: Li Hui, China’s special representative for Eurasian affairs, is expected to begin his trip on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Soldiers from Ukraine’s 72nd Mechanized Brigade firing at Russian positions in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last week.

item.title: A Crucial Question in Thailand’s Election: Can You Criticize the King?
item.description: Liberal voters have intensified their scrutiny of the Thai monarchy in recent years. Conservatives have responded with a campaign to defend the institution at all costs.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A policeman standing guard in front of a portrait of King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, during anti-government protests in Bangkok in 2020.

item.title: Migrants Deported to Mexico Face Criminals and Predatory Officials
item.description: Those made to leave the U.S. face gangs and a Mexican asylum system where cases linger for years.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants near a wire barrier on the northern bank of the Rio Grande along the border between Brownsville, Texas, and Matamoros, Mexico.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Risk Their Lives to Keep Weapons From the Black Market
item.description: They can’t track every shell, but at a time of heightened scrutiny in Washington they know they can ill afford slips with the big ticket items.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The 59th Motorized Brigade of the Ukrainian Ground Forces firing a howitzer at a Russian position in early May.

item.title: Once an Evangelist for Airbnbs, She Now Crusades for Affordable Housing
item.description: Precious Price ditched her profitable business of renting home stays to tourists to combat the mounting housing crisis.
item.dc:creator: Martha C. White
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Precious Price, a former home-share host, sits in front of her tiny house that is in her Atlanta backyard. She now rents out her main house to local tenants, forfeiting lucrative short-term tourist bookings.

item.title: Chinese Dissident Sentenced to 8 Years After He Tried to Fly to His Dying Wife
item.description: The activist Yang Maodong said he had only wanted China to “fully realize authentic freedom, democracy, human rights and rule of law.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The timing of Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier removing branches that had concealed a howitzer.

item.title: ‘I Don’t Know What the Future Holds’: An Afghan Family at the U.S. Border
item.description: Hours before the end of Title 42, a family of six from Afghanistan awaited their fate at the border wall in Tijuana, Mexico, after traveling through more than a dozen countries.
item.dc:creator: Noah Throop, Sarah Kerr and Caroline Kim

item.title: Zelensky, Citing Equipment Gaps, Says It’s Too Soon for Counteroffensive
item.description: Ukraine’s president played down the chance of an imminent military move, but the claim was greeted with some skepticism.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Shashank Bengali, Lara Jakes and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian marines removing branches that had concealed a howitzer before firing at a Russian target from a wooded position on Wednesday.

item.title: Sudan’s Clashing Forces Agree to Allow Aid In, but Not to a Truce, U.S. Says
item.description: Officials hope the agreement will allow the delivery of lifesaving aid and ease conditions for the millions of Sudanese suffering after nearly four weeks of fighting between rival generals.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Michael Crowley
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Sudanese Army soldiers in southern Khartoum, last week.

item.title: Karl Jenkins Sets the Record Straight: He Is Not Meghan Markle
item.description: Online jokesters claimed that Karl Jenkins was the Duchess of Sussex in disguise at the coronation. He sets the record straight.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:description: Karl Jenkins, a Welsh composer, attended the coronation of King Charles III because one of his harp compositions was being performed.

item.title: Kemal Dervis, Who Eased Turkey’s Economic Crisis, Dies at 74
item.description: Changes he spearheaded in 2001 helped avert disaster. He later led the United Nations Development Program.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: The economist Kemal Dervis in 2008, when he was in charge of the United Nations Development Program.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Guide to the Thai Elections
item.description: Today, our Southeast Asia bureau chief explains what’s at stake in the Thai election. Also, a court in Pakistan ordered the release of Imran Khan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Justin Porter
item.media:description: A voter casts his ballot during advance voting at a polling station in a school in Narathiwat, southern Thailand, on May 7, 2023, a week ahead of the May 14 general election.

item.title: Days After Crowning the King, Archbishop Condemns U.K. Migrant Plan
item.description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury and a member of the House of Lords, told Parliament that the government’s plan to deal with immigration is “morally unacceptable.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, at Westminster Abbey on the day of the coronation of King Charles III.

item.title: What Song Represents Your Home?
item.description: Tell us why it evokes the spirit of the place where you live.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: W.H.O. Ends Mpox Global Emergency
item.description: The virus was contained in most countries with a combination of vaccination and behavioral change.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Kholood Eid for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mobile mpox vaccination facility in Manhattan last fall.

item.title: Erdogan’s Election Prospects Take a Hit as a Challenger Drops Out
item.description: With Turks going to the polls on Sunday, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had hoped for a swift victory. But the departure of one challenger is likely to benefit his main competitor.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election posters for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Kayseri, Turkey, in April.

item.title: Top U.S. Official Accused South Africa of Providing Weapons to Russia
item.description: The American ambassador to South Africa told reporters that Washington is confident a Russian ship picked up a load of weapons and ammunition near Cape Town in December.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The Russian ship Lady R, top left, docked at Simon’s Town Naval Base in Cape Town. A top U.S. official contended that the ship “uploaded weapons and ammunition.”
